Authors:
Yang Gui, Guosheng Zhu, Philippe Callac, Kevin D Hyde, Luis
A Parra, Jie Chen, Tongjing Yang, Wanbing Huang, Guanglu Gong, Zuoyi
Liu
Title:
Agaricus section Arvenses: three new species and high
potential biodiversity at a climatic crossroads in subtropical Southwest
China
Abstract:
Agaricus is a genus of saprobic basidiomycetes with more
than 400 species recognized worldwide, but with only about 50 species
known in China. Species of Agaricus section Arvenses are consumed
throughout the world and several species of this section, such as A.
subrufescens, are cultivated for their nutritional and medicinal
properties. Our objective was to investigate the species diversity of
section Arvenses in subtropical Southwest China. Among numerous
collections we selected 30 wild specimens belonging to eight likely
species of this section. A phylogenetic analysis based on the rDNA-ITS
region and including 22 species of section Arvenses from GenBank showed
that the section Arvenses was monophyletic and subdivided in five major
branches. The branch of A. subrufescens arose near the common ancestor
of the section, while the other species grouped in four clades (A-D):
the four typically tropical species grouped in clade A, the four
Australasian species grouped in clade B, and 12 non-tropical species
from the Northern hemisphere clustered in clades C and D, while position
of A. augustus remained uncertain. Interestingly, the eight species from
subtropical Southwest China were distributed in the five branches of the
section and were identified as follows. Agaricus guizhouensis (clade D),
A. longistipes (C), and A. megalocarpus (B) are described as new
species. Agaricus abruptibulbus (D), A. flocculosipes (A), and A.
subrufescens are newly reported species for Guizhou Province. Two
probable new species are in clade D. The distribution of the eight
Chinese species in five branches of the section indicates that
subtropical Southwest China is at the geographic and climatic
crossroads. Species in clades C and D which typically have a white or
yellowish pileus, are common in China, Europe and North America, while
they appear to be absent in neighboring tropical areas. The origin of
the white pileus trait, the close relationship between the âwhiteâ
species of clade D, and the potential nutritional and medicinal interest
of the newly revealed biodiversity are discussed. These data based on
first investigations in subtropical Southwest China suggest a potential
species richness that remains to be discovered.
